children.name: when a mode of transport leaves
pull out b2
children.definition: pull out if atrainpulls out, it slowly gains speed as it leaves the station at the start of a journey: rời bến
examples: we got there just as the train was pulling out.
a car pulled right out in front of me.

children.name: go b1
children.definition: go especiallyspokento leave:
examples: do you know what time the next bus goes?
mainly ukwhat time does the last train to bath go?

children.name: leave a1
children.definition: leave
examples: her plane leaves hong kong at 10.00.
when we arrived at the bus station, the bus had just left.
leave for/from

children.name: depart b1
children.definition: depart to leave - used especially inofficialinformationabouttimeswhen trains, planes, buses etc leave :khởi hành
examples: the bus was due to depart at any moment.
depart from
ocean liners arriving at and departing from the island
the 12.15 shuttle service to atlanta will depart from platform 16.
depart for
the 06:33 pullman will depart from london euston from platform 4.
the train departs waterloo at 09:00 hours on saturday.
flights by air europe depart gatwick on tuesdays.
registerin everyday english, people usually sayleaveorgorather thandepart:
what time does the next planeleave/go?
sheleft forgermany last week.
flightsleavefrom gatwick on tuesdays.

children.name: slip away c2
children.definition: slip out/away/ˌslɪp ˈaʊt, əˈweɪ/  to leavequietlyand without beingnoticed:
examples: lẻn ra ngoài, lẻn đi
▪ harriet glanced around, wondering if she could slip out unnoticed.
slip out/away to do something
▪ when everyone was busy talking i slipped away to join beth for a quiet drink.

children.name: sneak away c2
children.definition: sneak off/away/out to leavequietlytaking care not to be seen, usually when you want to do sth else: lẻn đi , trốn đi , trốn ra ngoài
examples: occasionally she and a friend would sneak off during their free study hour.
sneak off/away/out from
i don’t know what he’s up to, but he sneaks away from work early every tuesday.
we tried to sneak off from work early.
sneak off/away/out to
annie had sneaked out to the bar, hoping that her parents wouldn’t notice she was gone.

children.name: slope off x
children.definition: slope off/ˌsləʊp ˈɒf/  britishinformalto leave somewhere quietly and secretly, especially when you are avoiding work:
examples: ▪ while the manager was away, brian took the opportunity to slope off home an hour early every day.
slope off to
▪ ‘where’s sam?’ ‘i saw him sloping off to the pub half an hour ago.’

children.name: slink away x
children.definition: slink off/away/ˌslɪŋk ˈɒf, əˈweɪ/  to leave somewhere quietly, without being seen, especially because you are ashamed or afraid:
examples: ▪ alyssia had dumped her fiancé just two weeks before the wedding, and then slunk off to the south of france.
slinkverb[i usually + adv/prep ]slunk,slunklén, lẩn, lẻn
to walk away from somewhere quietly so that you are not noticed
_i tried to slink out of the room so that nobody would see me go.
_disapprovinghe usually slinksoff(= leaves) at about 3.30.

children.name: force yourself away
children.definition: tear/ to leave aplaceorpersonveryunwillinglybecause youhaveto:ép mình rời khỏi
examples: the view was so magnificent that it was difficult to tear ourselves away.
tear/force yourself away from
jake watched as police officers examined the body. it was a horrible sight, but he couldn’t tear himself away from it.

children.name: can’t bear to leave
children.definition: /goalsofind it difficult to leave to feel it is extremely difficult to leave apersonorplacethat youlikevery much:
examples: kim couldn’t bear to leave danny, and cried all the way to the airport.
ballesteros has always found it difficult to leave his home in pedrena.
can hardly bearto leave
we’d had such a great vacation, we could hardly bear to leave.

children.name: abandon b2
children.definition: abandon to go away makes it impossible for you to stay: bỏ đi
examples: we had to abandon the car and walk the rest of the way.
fearing further attacks, most of the population had abandoned the city.
by the time the rebel troops arrived, the village had already been abandoned.
from a place, vehicle etc permanently, especially because the situation
abandonment[u]
the abandonment of the island followed nuclear tests in the area.

children.name: spoken: telling sb angrily to go away
get lost x
children.definition: get lost/push off/ clear off uk said when you want someone to go away because they are annoying you: cút xéo
examples: i’ve told you before that we don’t need our windows cleaning, so just clear off and don’t come back!
look, just push off will you. you’re getting on my nerves.
get lost you creep! stop following me.

children.name: go away b1
children.definition: go away
examples: i wish you’d all just go away and leave me alone!
major ferguson opened a window, and shouted to the waiting reporters: ‘you’re wasting your time. go away!’

children.name: beat it x
children.definition: beat it/take a hike us informal said when you want sb to go away because they are annoying you: cút xéo
examples: beat it, you two. i’ve had enough of you for one day.

children.name: to leave at the start of a journey
go b1
children.definition: go especiallyspokento leave:
examples: let’s go!
the trip is all planned - we’re going in september.
i’ve packed all my bags, and i’m ready to go.

children.name: leave a1
children.definition: leave
examples: i have to leave early tomorrow morning to fly to detroit.
her plane leaves hong kong at 10.00.
when are you leaving to go on holiday?
when we arrived at the bus station, the bus had just left.
leave for/from
i’m leaving for paris on tuesday.
coaches leave from victoria every hour.

children.name: be off b1
children.definition: be off ukinformalto leave and begin a journey:
examples: i think we’d better be off now - it’ll take at least an hour to get to the airport.
be off to
when are you off to canada?
drive off [i pv] to quickly start driving a car away from somewhere:
eddie ran out of the house, jumped into his car, and drove off.
someone had smashed into her car, and then just driven off.
adrian just had time to see his father jump into the truck and drive off in a cloud of dust.
i got in the car and drove off.

children.name: i’m off b1
children.definition: i’m offuk /i’m outta hereus informal
examples: okay, i’m off now.
right. i’m off to bed.
that’s it. i’m outta here!

children.name: i must go b1
children.definition: i must gouk /igottagous said when you have to go somewhere:
examples: anyway, i gotta go. catch up with you later.
i must be going
i must be going. i’ve got to pick the kids up at four.

children.name: i must dash b2
children.definition: i must dash/ flyuk said when you have to hurry: phải nhanh
examples: i’ll have another coffee ,and then i must dash.

children.name: i’d better make tracks x
children.definition: i’d better make tracks/i’d better make a moveuk said when you want to start getting ready to leave soon:
examples: we’d better make tracks, or we’ll miss our train.
i think we’d better make a move before it gets dark.

children.name: i’m getting out of here b1
children.definition: i’m getting out of heresaid when you want to leave quickly to avoiddangeror sthunpleasant:
examples: oh no. it’s him again. i’m getting out of here!

children.name: walk out x
children.definition: walk out to leave an event such as a meeting or performance because you are angry or disapprove of sth :bỏ đi, ra về
examples: furious by now, i walked out, leaving him sitting there shocked and white-faced.
all the parents walked out (ofthe meeting) in protest.

children.name: storm out x
children.definition: storm out to leave a room after a quarrel in a very noisy and angry way: lao ra
examples: she yelled at me and stormed out, slamming the door behind her.
storm out of
he has been known to storm out of meetings on several occasions.
he stormed out of the house, slamming the door as he went.

children.name: flounce out x
children.definition: flounce out if sb, especially a woman, flounces out of a room, meeting, restaurant etc, she leaves in a way which shows that she is angry or thinks she has been treated unfairly:
examples: ‘i’m not putting up with your sexist comments any more,’ said gilly, flouncing out.
flounce out of
she flounced out of the restaurant, got into her car, and drove off into the night.

children.name: to go away from a place
go b1
children.definition: go especially spoken to leave:
examples: let’s go.
when does the next bus go?
we stayed another ten minutes and then we went.
i’ll have to go soon - was there anything else you wanted to talk about?
don’t go just yet - it’s not that late!
what time does the last train go?
right, let’s go!
she turned to go.
be/get going
it’s late! i must get going.

children.name: leave a1
children.definition: leave
examples: just as i was leaving, the phone rang.
i want to see you before i leave.
the police wanted to know what time he had left the office.
hand back the identity card when you leave the building.

children.name: go away b1
children.definition: go away to leave a place, often for alongtime orpermanently: đi xa
examples: i’m going away next week. would you mind feeding the cat for me?
‘are you going away this summer?’ ‘yes, we’re going to greece in august.’
he’s been really unhappy since she went away.
go away and leave me alone!

children.name: go off b1
children.definition: go off to leave a placesuddenlyor for a particular purpose, especially if you donotexplainwhy you are going: cứ thế đi
examples: they just went off, without even saying goodbye.
many trainees don’t finish the course and go off and work in other areas.
go off to do sth
when we could not find out what was wrong with the car, billy went off to find a phone.

children.name: set off b2
children.definition: set off/out to start alongjourney or start going somewhere, especially if your journey has been planned or has a special purpose:khởi hành, rời đi
examples: ▪ what time do you have to set off in the morning?
▪ we had meant to set out before lunch but nobody was ready to leave.
set off/out towards/along/in the direction of etc
▪ packing herself a couple of sandwiches, she set off along the cliff path.
▪ the weather had been fine on the morning that the climbers set out up the last part of the mountain.
set off/out for
▪ my mother was only twenty when she married my father and set off for addis ababa.
set off/out from
▪ the royal navy set out from portsmouth on july 13th.
set off/out to do
▪ columbus set out to discover america in the fifteenth century.

children.name: start for a1
children.definition: start for to start a journey to a particular place:bắt đầu ( đi đâu )
examples: when are you starting for seattle?
it was already dark by the time we started for home.

children.name: hit the road x
children.definition: hit the road informal to start a journey:lên đường
examples: ▪ it’s time we hit the road.
▪ the group will be hitting the road again in the new year, in order to promote their new album.

children.name: get going c2
children.definition: get going/moving informal to start a journey or start going somewhere, especially when you are late or when there has been a delay: lên đường
examples: let’s get going now or we’ll miss the train.
we'd better get moving or we'll be late.
the coach was supposed to leave at 10:30 but we eventually got going at 3 o'clock.
get going, you two! didn’t you hear the school bell?

children.name: start off b1
children.definition: start off to start moving away from a place where you have been, especially if you are driving a car, riding a bicycle etc:bắt đầu đi (thường là phương tiện cá nhân)
examples: before starting off you should check that your seat and mirrors are properly adjusted.
start off along/towards/down etc
the riders got back on their horses and started off along the track again.
